original_title: Sri Lanka stocks gain with highest turnover in 2months on debt restructuring confidence
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stocks closed near a one-week high on Friday, ending the month on a positive note with the highest turnover in nearly two months, as the banking sector gained confidence after the Central Bank Governor’s statement on domestic debt restructuring, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index closed up 0.79 percent or 72.59 points at 9,301.09.
“The market ended positively over confidence in domestic debt restructuring and revived indexes that were down during the week,” said Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings.
Sri Lanka will not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and will engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary “optimization,” Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

“There will be some treatment on central bank-held Treasury bills, and other Treasury bill holdings will not be treated. Treasury bonds, we envisage voluntary optimization,” Governor Nandal Weerasinghe told a creditor presentation Thursday.
Related; Sri Lanka will not restructure T-bills outside Central Bank, bonds voluntary: Governor
The market generated a turnover of 4.2 billion rupees, above the daily average of 1.8 billion rupees, and the highest since February 3, 2023.
Turnover was mainly generated by the Insurance and banking sector counters and was also pushed by crossings from LOLC and John Keells Holdings, on positive affirmations on debt restructuring.
Previously, fears of debt restructuring mainly affected the banking and financial sectors, which dragged the index down, and the Central Bank Governor pushed poor sentiment upwards.
“Investors adopted a wait-and-see approach after the IMF loan facility got approved, due to domestic debt restructuring, and the Governor’s statement gave investors some clarity,” Ranatunga said.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, closed up 1.23 percent or 32.86 points at 2,697.12.
The market saw a net foreign outflow of 2.5 billion rupees, and the total offshore outflows recorded so far in 2023 were 2.9 billion rupees.
Top gainers were Hatton National Bank, Expolanka, and Commercial Bank. (Colombo/Mar 31/2023)
